Description: The BFA in Art with a concentration in Photography is designed for students who desire a comprehensive curriculum in photography, encompassing contemporary photographic practice and theory, art history, and a strong foundation in visual arts. The program emphasizes conceptual and technical skills, critical thinking, and professional practices within the field of photography. Students will explore diverse photographic mediums and approaches, including digital, analog, and alternative processes, preparing them for careers as artists, educators, and professionals in various photographic fields.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Fine Arts in Printmaking
Requirements: Admission to the BFA is a two-step process. First, prospective BFA students must apply to the university through Cal State Apply. Second, students must submit a portfolio for review to the School of Art. To be considered for admission to the BFA in Art degree program in any of the options, a student must meet the general requirements for admission to the university. In addition to the university application, a portfolio of art work is required for admission to the BFA in Art, for all options. Once the university application is submitted, students will be given a link to the Art portfolio submission on SlideRoom.
Description: Students in the BFA Art Option in Printmaking will acquire both traditional and contemporary technical and conceptual understanding of the art of printmaking. The program emphasizes a broad approach to printmaking as an art form and a relevant contemporary practice. Students will develop their ability to make informed creative decisions and think critically about their work, the medium, and its cultural context. This focus prepares students for a diverse range of careers in the visual arts field including exhibition, graduate school, and other professional applications.
CostPerCredit: $396 (for non-residents, in addition to base tuition and fees)
ScholarshipType: Merit-based, Need-based, Campus/Community Activities, Work Experience

ProgramName: Bachelor of Fine Arts in Sculpture
Requirements: To be considered for admission to CSULB as a first-year student, you must be a high school graduate, have completed the A-G college preparatory subjects, and meet the GPA requirements. For the Bachelor of Fine Arts in Sculpture, major-specific requirements include a 2.5 GPA in the preparatory courses (ART 130, ART 131, ART 181 and AH 111A or 111B) and successfully passing a portfolio review.
Description: The Sculpture program provides students with the opportunity to develop skills in a wide range of sculptural materials and processes. Students are exposed to traditional and contemporary approaches, including carving, modeling, fabrication, casting, installation, and digital fabrication. The program emphasizes critical thinking and conceptual development, encouraging students to explore their personal vision and engage with contemporary issues through their artwork.
CostPerCredit: $420 (for non-residents, in addition to basic tuition and fees)

ProgramName: Bachelor of Music in Music Performance
Requirements: In addition to applying to the university through Cal State Apply, all applicants for the BM in Performance must also apply to the Bob Cole Conservatory of Music through the BCCM application on GetAcceptd. This requires an audition.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Aerospace Engineering
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Aerospace Engineering program at California State University, Long Beach, is nationally recognized for its excellence in preparing students for successful careers in the dynamic aerospace industry. Our program provides a comprehensive education that blends theoretical knowledge with practical, hands-on experience, ensuring graduates are well-equipped to tackle real-world challenges. Students in the program develop a strong foundation in core engineering principles, including aerodynamics, propulsion, structures, flight mechanics, and control systems. The curriculum emphasizes critical thinking, problem-solving, and design skills through various projects and laboratory sessions. Our dedicated faculty members are experts in their fields, committed to providing a supportive and engaging learning environment. Graduates of the program are highly sought after by leading aerospace companies, government agencies, and research institutions for roles in design, analysis, testing, and manufacturing of aircraft and spacecraft.
Accredidation: Accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, www.abet.org.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Applied Data Science
Requirements: To be considered for admission to CSULB, freshmen applicants must meet the following minimum requirements: 1. Complete the 15-unit comprehensive “A-G” pattern of college preparatory courses. 2. Have a 2.50 or greater “A-G” grade point average (GPA) if you are a California resident or a 3.00 or greater “A-G” GPA if you are a non-California resident. 3. Graduate from high school or receive a G.E.D. or California High School Proficiency Examination Certificate. Note: CSULB is not accepting applications from students seeking a second bachelor’s degree.
Department: College of Natural Sciences and Mathematics
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Applied Data Science is a highly interdisciplinary program that draws faculty from various departments and colleges across the university. The program is designed to provide students with a strong theoretical and practical foundation in the interdisciplinary field of data science. Students will gain the knowledge and skills necessary to collect, organize, analyze, interpret, and visualize data from various sources to extract valuable insights and make data-driven decisions. The curriculum emphasizes the application of data science principles and techniques to real-world problems in various domains. Graduates will be well-prepared for careers in data science, data analytics, business intelligence, machine learning, and related fields across various industries.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Biochemistry
Requirements:
To be considered for admission to CSULB as a freshman, you must meet the following minimum requirements:
1. Complete the A-G course requirements with a grade of 'C-' or better.
2. Meet the minimum CSULB GPA requirements.
3. Graduate from high school.
Department: College of Natural Sciences and Mathematics
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Biochemistry provides an intensive education in the core areas of chemistry and an emphasis in the biological aspects of chemistry. This major is certified by the American Chemical Society. The coursework and laboratory experiences prepare students for employment in a wide variety of biochemistry-related careers and for graduate study in biochemistry, chemistry or related fields. Graduates of the program are well-prepared for professional programs in medicine, dentistry, pharmacy, and veterinary medicine. Students interested in the biochemistry major should contact the Chemistry and Biochemistry Department office.
Accredidation: Certified by the American Chemical Society.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Biology, Option in Biology Education
Requirements:
To be considered for admission to CSULB as a first-year student, you must meet the following minimum requirements:
1. Be a high school graduate or have the equivalent.
2. Complete the 15-unit comprehensive 'A-G' pattern of college preparatory courses.
3. Have a qualifying 'A-G' grade point average (GPA).
Department: College of Natural Sciences and Mathematics

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Biology, Option in General Biology
Requirements:
To be considered for admission to CSULB as a freshman, you must meet the following minimum requirements:
1. Be a high school graduate or have the equivalent.
2. Complete the 15-unit comprehensive “a-g” pattern of college preparatory courses.
3. Earn a qualifying “a-g” grade point average (GPA).
Department: College of Natural Sciences and Mathematics
Description: The Bachelor of Science (B.S.) in Biological Sciences provides students with a broad and rigorous exposure to the biological sciences. The General Biology option is suitable for students planning careers in a variety of areas including professional careers (e.g., medicine, dentistry, pharmacy, physical therapy, etc.), biotechnology, or environmental biology. Students are prepared to pursue graduate studies in various fields of biology. The curriculum is designed to provide breadth of exposure to biological principles and depth of exposure in one or more areas of the biological sciences. The B.S. in Biological Sciences provides strong training in the physical sciences which serves as a foundation for rigorous training in biology.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Biology, Option in Marine Biology
Requirements: As a prospective freshman, you must meet the standard admission requirements for CSULB and any additional major-specific requirements. Standard requirements include being a high school graduate or equivalent and completing the 15-unit comprehensive 'a-g' pattern of college preparatory courses. To be considered for the Biology major, you must complete a-g courses with a C- or better and have a minimum unweighted 3.0 high school GPA from a-g courses.
Department: College of Natural Sciences and Mathematics
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Biology, Option in Marine Biology, is designed for students interested in the study of marine organisms, ecosystems, and conservation. This option provides a strong foundation in biological principles while focusing on the unique aspects of marine environments, including oceanography, marine ecology, ichthyology, marine invertebrate zoology, and marine microbiology. Students gain practical experience through laboratory work, field trips to local marine habitats, and opportunities for research with faculty specializing in marine science. The curriculum prepares graduates for careers in marine research, environmental consulting, wildlife management, aquaculture, conservation, and for further graduate studies in marine biology or related fields.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Biology, Option in Microbiology
Requirements: To be considered for admission to CSULB, freshman applicants must meet the following minimum requirements: be a high school graduate or have the equivalent, complete the 15-unit comprehensive 'a-g' pattern of college preparatory courses, and earn a qualifying 'a-g' GPA. As Biology is an impacted major, applicants will be admitted based on their self-reported high school GPA in 'a-g' courses and may be required to submit additional information for supplemental consideration. The minimum GPA for admission may be higher than the stated minimums due to the number of applications or the quality of the applicant pool.
Department: College of Natural Sciences and Mathematics
Description: The Microbiology option provides specialized coursework in the study of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi, and protozoa. Students will gain knowledge and skills in microbial genetics, physiology, immunology, and pathogenesis.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Biology, Option in Molecular Cell Biology and Physiology
Requirements: Freshman admission to the College of Natural Sciences and Mathematics is 'major-specific'. Applicants will be considered for admission into their alternate major only if they are CSU-eligible and not admitted into their first-choice major. To be considered for admission into a CNSM major, applicants must have a minimum of 'B' in all completed high school math courses through the junior year. In addition, all other CSU admissions requirements must be met for consideration.
Department: College of Natural Sciences and Mathematics
Description: The option in Cell and Molecular Biology and Physiology offers an interdisciplinary approach to the study of life at the cellular and molecular level. Students in this option examine the fundamental processes of living organisms, including genetics, metabolism, signal transduction, and physiological regulation. Through a combination of coursework, laboratory experiences, and research opportunities, students gain a deep understanding of how cells function, interact, and contribute to the overall physiology of an organism. This option prepares students for careers in biotechnology, biomedical research, pharmaceuticals, and health professions, as well as for graduate studies in cell biology, molecular biology, physiology, and related fields.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Biology, Option in Zoology, Botany, and Ecology
Requirements:
General Freshman Admission Requirements (for admission to the University):
1. Graduate from high school or have the legal equivalent.
2. Complete the 15-unit comprehensive “A-G” pattern of college preparatory courses.
3. Earn a qualifying “A-G” grade point average (GPA).

Program-Specific Requirements (for declaring the major after admission to CSULB as a Biology Pre-Baccalaureate major):
1. A minimum cumulative GPA of 2.5.
2. Completion of BIOL 211, BIOL 212, and CHEM 111A, each with a grade of “C” or better.
3. Completion of MATH 119A or MATH 122 with a grade of “C” or better.
Department: College of Natural Sciences and Mathematics
Concentration: Option in Zoology, Botany, and Ecology
Description: The Bachelor of Science (BS) degree in Biology offers three options for students interested in specializing in different aspects of the biological sciences. The Option in Zoology, Botany, and Ecology provides students with a broad education across organismal and ecological biology and prepares them for careers in research, conservation, education, and various biological industries, or for graduate studies.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Biomedical Engineering
Requirements: To be considered for admission to CSULB, freshman applicants must meet the following minimum requirements: be a high school graduate or have a GED; complete the 15-unit college preparatory "A-G" course pattern with a grade of C or better; and have a minimum 2.5 "A-G" GPA for California residents or a 3.0 for non-California residents. As a highly-impacted major, Biomedical Engineering also requires applicants to complete the following supplemental requirements by the end of their spring term: a minimum of B in high school Chemistry, a minimum of B in high school Physics, and enrollment in Pre-Calculus, Calculus, or AP Calculus.
Description: The Bachelor of Science (BS) in Biomedical Engineering program provides students with a strong foundation in engineering sciences and their application to the field of medicine and biology. Biomedical engineers apply traditional engineering methods and new methodologies to solve problems in biology and medicine to improve human health. Students in the program will learn to design, develop, and maintain medical equipment and systems; design and construct artificial organs, prostheses, and devices; and research new biological and physiological systems. Graduates are prepared for careers in medical device manufacturing, pharmaceuticals, biotechnology, and hospitals, or for graduate studies in biomedical engineering, medicine, and other health-related fields.
Accredidation: The Biomedical Engineering program is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, https://www.abet.org.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Business Administration
Requirements:
To be considered for admission to CSULB as a freshman, you must meet the following minimum requirements:
1. Be a high school graduate or have the legal equivalent of a high school diploma.
2. Complete the 15-unit comprehensive “a-g” pattern of college preparatory courses. To meet the subject requirements, you must complete the courses with a grade of C- or better.
3. Earn a qualifying “a-g” grade point average (GPA).
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Business Administration (BSBA) provides students with a broad and solid understanding of business practices. Students learn about the fundamental principles of business, develop a global perspective, and enhance their analytical and critical thinking skills. The program provides the knowledge and skills necessary for a successful career in a dynamic global business environment.
Accredidation: The College of Business at California State University, Long Beach is fully accredited by AACSB International – The Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business. AACSB is the premier accrediting agency for business schools worldwide. Less than five percent of the more than 16,000 schools of business worldwide have earned AACSB accreditation. AACSB-accredited schools have the highest quality faculty, relevant and challenging curriculum, and provide educational and career opportunities that are not found at other business schools. AACSB accreditation assures stakeholders that business schools will provide a high-quality education to future business leaders.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Chemical Engineering
Description: The undergraduate program in Chemical Engineering at CSULB provides students with a strong foundation in core chemical engineering principles, including thermodynamics, fluid mechanics, heat and mass transfer, reaction kinetics, and process control. The curriculum emphasizes both theoretical understanding and practical application, preparing graduates for a wide range of careers in industries such as chemical manufacturing, petroleum, pharmaceuticals, biotechnology, environmental engineering, and materials science. Students gain hands-on experience through laboratory work, design projects, and internships, fostering problem-solving skills and critical thinking.
Accredidation: The Bachelor of Science in Chemical Engineering program is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, http://www.abet.org.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Chemistry
Requirements: General admission to CSULB is competitive and the university considers a multi-factor admission model for all freshman applicants. These factors include High School coursework (A-G courses), Grade Point Average (GPA), preparation for the intended major, the applicant's school and geographic location, and other personal attributes and experiences. The Bachelor of Science in Chemistry does not have additional major-specific admission requirements beyond the general university requirements for freshmen.
Department: College of Natural Sciences and Mathematics
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Chemistry provides students with a thorough background in all areas of chemistry and meets the professional standards for certification by the American Chemical Society. Students in the B.S. in Chemistry program are also well prepared for graduate work in chemistry or allied fields, and for careers as professional chemists.
Accredidation: meets the professional standards for certification by the American Chemical Society
CostPerCredit: $420 per unit for non-residents (in addition to basic tuition & fees)

ProgramName: Bachelor_of_Science_in_Civil_Engineering
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Construction Management program at CSULB is designed to prepare students for professional careers in the construction industry. The program provides a comprehensive education in construction management principles, practices, and technologies. Students gain knowledge in areas such as project planning and control, cost estimating, scheduling, construction methods, safety, and legal aspects of construction. The curriculum emphasizes practical application through hands-on projects, case studies, and field experiences, ensuring graduates are well-equipped to manage complex construction projects effectively.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Computer Engineering
Requirements: You will be required to submit the following documents to the Center for International Education after you have submitted your Cal State Apply application: Official Transcripts/Academic Records from all high schools/secondary schools and colleges/universities attended. Official English Language Proficiency test scores (TOEFL, IELTS, PTE, or Duolingo) are required if the language of instruction at your school was not English. A copy of your passport biographical page.
Description: The Computer Engineering program is jointly administered by the Department of Electrical Engineering and the Department of Computer Engineering and Computer Science. It provides students with fundamental knowledge in both hardware and software aspects of computer systems. Graduates of the program are well prepared for a wide range of careers in designing, developing, and testing computer hardware, software, and embedded systems, or for graduate studies in computer engineering or related disciplines.
Accredidation: The Computer Engineering program is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, https://www.abet.org.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Computer Engineering Technology
Requirements:
To be considered for admission to CSULB as a freshman, you must meet the following minimum requirements:
1. Be a high school graduate or have the equivalent.
2. Complete the 15-unit comprehensive 'a-g' pattern of college preparatory courses.
3. Have a qualifying 'a-g' grade point average (GPA).
Description: Computer Engineering Technology (CET) at CSULB is a hands-on, practice-oriented program. It covers fundamental principles and applications of computer hardware, software, and networking. The program prepares students for careers that require the application of current and emerging computer technologies for the design, development, and implementation of computer systems. Graduates will have the ability to analyze, design, and implement computer systems involving the integration of hardware and software. They will also be able to apply current and emerging technologies to the solution of computer engineering problems, and be able to communicate effectively through written and oral presentations.
Accredidation: The Bachelor of Science in Computer Engineering Technology program is accredited by the Engineering Technology Accreditation Commission of ABET, https://www.abet.org.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Computer Science
Requirements: Admission to all majors at CSULB is competitive. CSULB will continue to consider applicants based on the following factors: GPA, high school courses, and other supplemental factors such as work experience, extracurricular activities, and other available information that helps us to know the applicant better.
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Computer Science (BSCS) program prepares students for careers in the rapidly growing and evolving fields of computer science and software engineering. The program provides a strong foundation in theoretical computer science, including algorithms, data structures, and discrete mathematics, as well as practical skills in programming languages, software development, and computer systems. Students gain hands-on experience through projects, labs, and internships, developing critical thinking, problem-solving, and teamwork skills essential for success in the industry. Graduates are well-prepared for diverse roles such as software engineers, data scientists, cybersecurity analysts, and system administrators, and for pursuing graduate studies in computer science or related disciplines.
Accredidation: Accredited by ABET.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Construction Engineering Management
Requirements:
To be considered for admission to CSU Long Beach, First-Time, First-Year students must meet the following requirements:
1. Be a high school graduate or have the equivalent.
2. Complete the 15-unit comprehensive "a-g" pattern of college preparatory courses.
3. Have a qualifying "a-g" grade point average (GPA).

California residents must have a 2.50 or greater “a-g” GPA. Non-California residents must have a 3.00 or greater “a-g” GPA. The GPA is based on the “a-g” courses taken during the 10th and 11th grades of high school. The CSU does not use the plus/minus grading system for GPA calculation.
Description: Construction Engineering Management (CEM) combines civil engineering topics with construction management principles, preparing graduates to manage and implement civil infrastructure projects, such as highways, bridges, dams, buildings, and other facilities. Our graduates are problem solvers that manage people, materials, equipment, and money to deliver civil engineering projects. The CEM program focuses on civil engineering design and construction engineering principles that differentiate it from construction management programs typically housed in colleges of business. Our program prepares students for careers as construction engineers and construction managers. The curriculum provides a strong foundation in mathematics, physics, and basic engineering sciences and covers areas such as structural analysis and design, geotechnical engineering, water resources engineering, highway design, construction methods, cost estimating, scheduling, construction law, and project management. The curriculum also includes a capstone design project that integrates knowledge and skills gained from previous courses to solve real-world construction engineering management problems.
Accredidation: The Bachelor of Science in Construction Engineering Management is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, http://www.abet.org.
ScholarshipAmount: Awards range from $100 to $20,000 per academic year.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Construction Management
Requirements:
All applicants must apply during the initial filing period of October 1 through November 30. All applicants must meet the regular university admission requirements for the level at which they are applying (e.g., freshman, transfer). Due to the high-demand for this major, it has been declared 'impacted' and requires that applicants meet additional requirements. Refer to the 'Freshman Admission' and 'Transfer Admission' sections of this catalog for the most current criteria.

Freshman applicants must complete a core of high school courses. To be considered 'eligible' for the major, an applicant must have a Math Index of 3 or 4 by having completed Algebra I, Geometry, and Algebra II, and being enrolled in or having completed a math course with Algebra II as a prerequisite, and have a minimum unweighted GPA of 2.5.
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Construction Engineering Management (BSCEM) program at CSU Long Beach prepares students for diverse careers in the construction industry. Our curriculum is designed to provide students with a strong foundation in engineering principles, business management, and construction methods. Graduates are equipped to manage complex construction projects, from initial planning and design to execution and completion. The program emphasizes problem-solving, critical thinking, and ethical decision-making, ensuring students are well-rounded professionals ready to tackle the challenges of modern construction. We integrate hands-on learning, field trips, and industry speaker events to enhance the educational experience and connect students with real-world practices.
CostPerCredit: $420 (for non-residents, in addition to base tuition)

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Criminology and Criminal Justice
Department: School of Criminology, Criminal Justice, and Emergency Management
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Criminology and Criminal Justice provides students with a comprehensive understanding of crime and justice. The major emphasizes critical thinking, analytical skills, and ethical considerations, preparing students for various careers in law enforcement, corrections, courts, and victim services, as well as for graduate studies. The curriculum explores the causes of crime, the operation of the criminal justice system, and the social and legal responses to crime. Through a combination of theoretical knowledge and practical application, students gain insights into the complexities of crime, justice, and social control.
CostPerCredit: An additional $420 per unit for non-residents on top of standard tuition.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies, with individual awards often ranging from $500 to $5,000

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Earth Systems
Department: College of Natural Sciences and Mathematics
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Earth Systems provides a comprehensive and interdisciplinary study of the Earth, including its physical, chemical, biological, and human processes. This program integrates aspects of geology, oceanography, meteorology, environmental science, and remote sensing to understand the complex interactions within Earth's systems. Students will develop a strong foundation in scientific principles, quantitative analysis, and field techniques, preparing them for careers in environmental consulting, natural resource management, research, and education, or for advanced studies in Earth and environmental sciences. The curriculum emphasizes hands-on learning, critical thinking, and problem-solving skills to address current and future environmental challenges.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Electrical Engineering
Description:
The Bachelor of Science in Electrical Engineering curriculum prepares students for entry into the profession of electrical engineering and for further study at the graduate level. The curriculum provides a strong foundation in mathematics, physics, and general education, followed by a core of electrical engineering subjects, and a variety of elective courses in specialized areas of electrical engineering. The curriculum emphasizes hands-on experience through laboratory work and design projects throughout the program. The Electrical Engineering Program is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, http://www.abet.org.

Electrical Engineering Program Educational Objectives (PEOs):
The Electrical Engineering Program will prepare graduates to attain the following objectives within a few years of graduation:
1. Be employed in electrical engineering or related areas, and contribute to the economic development of the region, state, and nation.
2. Engage in professional development, continuing education, and/or graduate studies.
3. Conduct themselves as ethical and responsible professionals in local, national, and global communities.

Student Outcomes (SOs):
At the time of graduation, students in the Electrical Engineering program will be able to:
1. an ability to identify, formulate, and solve complex engineering problems by applying principles of engineering, science, and mathematics
2. an ability to apply engineering design to produce solutions that meet specified needs with consideration of public health, safety, and welfare, as well as global, cultural, social, environmental, and economic factors
3. an ability to communicate effectively with a range of audiences
4. an ability to recognize ethical and professional responsibilities in engineering situations and make informed judgments, which must consider the impact of engineering solutions in global, economic, environmental, and societal contexts
5. an ability to function effectively on a team whose members together provide leadership, create a collaborative and inclusive environment, establish goals, plan tasks, and meet objectives
6. an ability to develop and conduct appropriate experimentation, analyze and interpret data, and use engineering judgment to draw conclusions
7. an ability to acquire and apply new knowledge as needed, using appropriate learning strategies.
Accredidation: The Electrical Engineering Program is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, http://www.abet.org.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Electronics Engineering Technology
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Electronics Engineering Technology (BSEET) program at California State University, Long Beach (CSULB) prepares students for a wide range of technical and management careers in the electronics and high-tech industries. The curriculum focuses on the practical application of engineering principles, combining theoretical knowledge with hands-on experience in areas such as analog and digital electronics, microcontrollers, control systems, instrumentation, communication systems, and power electronics. Students develop skills in circuit design, testing, troubleshooting, and project management, making them highly sought after by employers. The program emphasizes problem-solving, critical thinking, and teamwork, ensuring graduates are well-equipped to adapt to evolving technological advancements and contribute effectively in a professional engineering environment.
Accredidation: The Bachelor of Science in Electronics Engineering Technology program is accredited by the Engineering Technology Accreditation Commission of ABET, https://www.abet.org.
CostPerCredit: $46 per unit (College of Engineering Course Fee)
CollegeApplicationFee: $8,767/Year (Tuition & Campus Fees) + $46/unit College of Engineering Course Fee

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Engineering Technology
Requirements: To be considered for admission to the B.S. in Engineering Technology, you must meet the general requirements for admission to the university as either a freshman or a transfer student.
Description: The B.S. in Engineering Technology (BSET) program emphasizes the application of scientific and engineering principles to the solution of practical problems. Engineering Technology students learn by doing. The curriculum is a blend of theory and application with a hands-on approach, utilizing state-of-the-art facilities in manufacturing, mechanical design, thermal-fluid systems, and automation. Graduates are prepared for a wide variety of careers in industry including product development, manufacturing, quality control, technical sales, and facilities management.
Accredidation: The Engineering Technology B.S. program is accredited by the Engineering Technology Accreditation Commission of ABET, https://www.abet.org.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Environmental Engineering
Requirements: All applicants must complete the Cal State Apply online application and pay the application fee. Freshman applicants must have completed the required A-G college preparatory courses in high school with a qualifying grade point average. International applicants must also submit official academic records, proof of English language proficiency (such as TOEFL or IELTS scores), a Financial Affidavit of Support with a bank statement, and a copy of their passport. For Fall 2025 applicants, CSULB will not consider SAT or ACT test scores for admission purposes.
Description: Environmental engineers protect people and the planet from pollution, climate change, and other global problems. They solve complex environmental problems through scientific, technical, and management principles. They design and construct water and wastewater treatment plants, manage solid and hazardous waste, develop alternative energy, manage air pollution, investigate contaminated sites, and implement regulations. They also work in government, industry, and consulting firms on a variety of environmental issues. The mission of the Bachelor of Science in Environmental Engineering program at CSULB is to produce graduates who are technically competent and ethically responsible to address environmental problems related to water, wastewater, stormwater, air, land, and energy resources. The goals of the program are to provide students with strong fundamentals in mathematics, science, and engineering; to provide a comprehensive education in environmental engineering; and to develop skills for professional success.
Accredidation: The Bachelor of Science in Environmental Engineering program is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, http://www.abet.org.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Environmental Science and Public Policy
Requirements: To be considered for admission to CSULB as a freshman, you must be a high school graduate, have completed the 'a-g' college preparatory subject requirements with a grade of C- or better, and have a qualifying 'a-g' GPA. The Environmental Science and Public Policy major does not have additional major-specific admission requirements beyond the university's general requirements.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Family and Consumer Sciences, Option in Child Development and Family Studies
Requirements:
Admission under Impaction: Refer to the Family and Consumer Sciences section of this catalog for details on impaction.
Major Specific Declaration Requirements: Students must earn a “C” or better in FCS 200, HDEV 190, NUTR 132, and PSY 100 before declaring the major and enrolling in any 300 level FCS courses.
Department: College of Health and Human Services
Description: The Bachelor of Arts in Child Development and Family Studies (CDFS) focuses on the study of children and families in diverse contexts. The program provides students with a strong foundation in theories, research, and practices related to individual and family development across the lifespan. Students will examine various aspects of child and family well-being, including cognitive, social, emotional, and physical development, as well as family dynamics, parenting, and cultural influences. The program prepares students for careers in child and family services, education, advocacy, and research, or for advanced studies in related fields. The CDFS program emphasizes critical thinking, ethical considerations, and culturally responsive practices.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Family and Consumer Sciences, Option in Consumer Affairs
Requirements: To be considered for freshman admission, applicants must be a high school graduate, have completed the required 15-unit comprehensive 'a-g' pattern of college preparatory courses, and have a qualifying 'a-g' GPA. Transfer applicants must meet minimum California State University eligibility requirements, including having 60 or more transferable semester units, a qualifying GPA, and completion of specific general education courses.
Description: The Option in Consumer Affairs is designed to prepare students for careers that help individuals and families improve the quality of their lives as consumers of goods and services. The curriculum provides students with a strong foundation in consumer theories, issues, and practices, emphasizing critical thinking, problem-solving, and ethical decision-making. Areas of study include consumer rights and responsibilities, consumer protection laws and regulations, personal finance, consumer advocacy, and market analysis.
CostPerCredit: $420 per unit for non-residents (in addition to standard tuition and fees)

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Family and Consumer Sciences, Option in Family Life Education
Requirements:
To be considered for admission to CSULB, freshman applicants must meet the following minimum requirements:
1. Complete the A-G course requirements with a grade of C- or better.
2. Have a 2.50 or greater GPA (for California residents or graduates of a California high school) or a 3.00 or greater GPA (for non-residents of California or non-graduates of a California high school).
3. Graduate from high school or have the legal equivalent of a high school diploma.
Department: College of Health and Human Services
ScholarshipType: University, President's, Departmental, College, and External Scholarships

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Finance
Requirements:
To be considered for admission to CSULB as a freshman, you must meet the following minimum requirements:
1. Be a high school graduate or have the legal equivalent of a high school diploma.
2. Complete the 15-unit comprehensive 'a-g' pattern of college preparatory courses. For admission, you must have a grade of 'C-' or better in each of the courses.
3. Earn a qualifying 'a-g' grade point average (GPA). California residents must have a minimum 2.50 GPA to be considered. Non-California residents must have a minimum 3.00 GPA to be considered.
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Finance provides a comprehensive curriculum in the theory and practice of finance and financial management. Students learn to apply finance theory to real-world problems and develop analytical skills in areas such as investments, corporate finance, financial planning, and financial institutions. The curriculum covers a wide range of topics, including financial markets, valuation, risk management, capital budgeting, and portfolio management. Graduates are prepared for careers in various sectors of the financial industry, including banking, investment management, corporate finance, financial planning, and real estate. The program also provides a strong foundation for graduate studies in finance or related fields.
Accredidation: The College of Business, which houses the Finance program, is accredited by AACSB International, the premier accrediting agency for business schools worldwide.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Geography
Requirements:
Freshmen admission to the Geography major is 'major-specific.' Applicants will be considered for 'pre-major' status in Geography based on the general CSULB freshmen admissions criteria. To be considered for freshmen admission to CSULB, you must meet the following minimum requirements:
1. Be a high school graduate or have a General Education Development (GED) certificate.
2. Complete the 15-unit A-G college preparatory course pattern with a grade of C or better.
3. Meet the minimum eligibility index for your academic status.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Geology
Requirements: To be considered for admission to CSULB, first-time freshmen applicants must meet the following minimum requirements: 1. Graduation from high school or equivalent; 2. Completion of the 15-unit comprehensive 'a-g' pattern of college preparatory courses; 3. Have a qualifying 'a-g' grade point average (GPA). CSULB is impacted for all undergraduate programs, and admission is competitive.
Department: College of Natural Sciences and Mathematics

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Health Care Administration, Option in Healthcare Data Analytics
Description: The Bachelor of Science (BS) in Health Care Administration prepares students for administrative positions in the growing health care industry. The department offers several options for students to specialize in a particular area of interest. The curriculum is constantly being updated to reflect new developments and demands in the dynamic health care sector. The program focuses on providing students with the leadership and management skills required to address current and future challenges in the health care industry. A critical component of the curriculum is the internship experience, which provides students with practical exposure to the health care field under the guidance of experienced professionals.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Health Care Administration, Option in Risk Management and Safety
Requirements:
To be considered for admission to CSULB, freshman applicants must meet the following minimum requirements:

1. Be a high school graduate or have the equivalent.
2. Complete the 15-unit comprehensive “a-g” pattern of college preparatory courses.
3. Have a qualifying “a-g” GPA.
Department: College of Health and Human Services
Description: The option in Risk Management and Safety provides students with knowledge and skills for entry- and mid-level positions in safety and risk management in both the private and public health care sector. The option prepares students to analyze problems, identify solutions, and implement strategies for addressing safety issues and minimizing risk. The curriculum incorporates knowledge in business practices, risk assessment and control, laws and regulations, environmental health, and emergency preparedness applicable to various health care settings.
Accredidation: Accredited by the Commission on Accreditation of Healthcare Management Education (CAHME).

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Health Science, Option in Community Health Education
Department: College of Health and Human Services
Description: Community Health Education (CHE) specialists are prepared to work in a variety of settings including governmental agencies, community-based organizations, hospitals, clinics, and private industry. CHE specialists develop, implement, and evaluate health education programs that promote, maintain, and improve individual and community health. They serve as a resource for current health information and programming in areas such as communicable and chronic diseases, maternal and child health, nutrition, physical activity, substance use, and mental health. The program prepares graduates for entry-level positions in a variety of health promotion settings and for graduate study in public health, health promotion, and other related fields. Our graduates are eligible to sit for the national Certified Health Education Specialist (CHES) examination. Learn more about the CHE option.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Health Science, Option in School Health Education
Description: This option prepares future educators to meet the needs of diverse student populations in the context of K-12 school health. The program provides the foundational knowledge, skills, and dispositions to promote the health of students, teachers, staff, and the wider school community. Students in the School Health Education Option learn to design, implement, and evaluate health education programs and services in school settings. The curriculum emphasizes critical thinking, cultural competency, and evidence-based practices relevant to contemporary school health challenges.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Hospitality and Tourism Management
Description: The Bachelor of Science (B.S.) in Hospitality Management prepares students for managerial careers in hospitality and tourism industries. The program also offers a Minor in Hospitality Management. This degree program prepares future hospitality industry leaders, with a strong focus on analytical skills, technology application, and global awareness.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Hospitality Management
Requirements: To be considered for admission to CSULB as a freshman, you must be a high school graduate, have completed the 15-unit comprehensive pattern of college preparatory courses (A-G curriculum), and have a qualifying 'a-g' grade point average (GPA). Students wishing to become Hospitality Management majors must first be admitted to the university.
Department: College of Health and Human Services
Description: The Bachelor of Science (BS) in Hospitality Management provides students with the academic foundation and practical experience necessary to become successful hospitality leaders. The program emphasizes a global perspective and focuses on the development of critical thinking, problem-solving, and leadership skills essential for managing various aspects of the hospitality industry. Students gain a comprehensive understanding of hospitality operations, finance, marketing, human resources, and strategic management, preparing them for diverse career opportunities in hotels, restaurants, resorts, event management, and other related sectors. The curriculum integrates theoretical knowledge with hands-on experiences, including internships, to ensure graduates are well-equipped to meet the challenges and demands of the dynamic global hospitality landscape.
Accredidation: The College of Business, which offers the Bachelor of Science in Hospitality Management program, is accredited by AACSB International – The Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Human Resource Management
Description: The Human Resources Management undergraduate program is committed to preparing students for careers in the dynamic and challenging field of Human Resources. Human Resources provides an organization with a competitive advantage through its people. The HR professional contributes to this by developing strategies and managing functions related to staffing, training and development, compensation, performance management, health and safety, employee and labor relations, and organizational development and change. Our graduates are highly sought after by organizations across industries and sectors including business, non-profit, and government. Our faculty are experts in the field, passionate about teaching, and committed to providing students with an excellent learning experience. The curriculum is comprehensive and aligned with industry standards, and is designed to provide students with the knowledge, skills, and abilities needed for success as an HR professional.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Information Systems
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Information Systems (BSIS) program is designed to provide students with the knowledge and skills necessary to design, develop, implement, and manage information systems within organizations. Information Systems professionals bridge the gap between business needs and technology solutions, playing a crucial role in modern enterprises. The curriculum covers a broad range of topics, including database management, systems analysis and design, programming, networking, cybersecurity, business intelligence, and project management. Students learn to apply theoretical concepts to real-world problems through hands-on projects, case studies, and internships. Graduates of the BSIS program are prepared for diverse career paths in areas such as systems analysis, IT consulting, data analysis, network administration, cybersecurity analysis, software development, and project management across various industries.
Accredidation: All programs in the College of Business are accredited by AACSB International – The Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business.
ScholarshipType: Merit-based, Need-based, Campus/community activities, Leadership skills

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in International Business
Requirements: As this is an undergraduate program, general university admission requirements apply. For first-year students, requirements include being a high school graduate, completing the 15-unit comprehensive 'a-g' pattern of college preparatory courses, and meeting a minimum 'college preparatory' GPA (2.50 or greater for California residents). For transfer students, minimum requirements include at least 60 transferable semester units, a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.0, being in good standing at the last institution attended, and completion of specific General Education courses with a grade of C or better. Admission to CSULB is competitive, and meeting the minimum CSU eligibility requirements does not guarantee admission.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Kinesiology, Option in Exercise Science
Department: College of Health and Human Services
ScholarshipType: Merit-based, need-based, or based on a specific talent or interest

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Kinesiology, Option in Fitness
Department: College of Health and Human Services
Description: The Fitness Option provides students with an understanding of physical activity, exercise, and health through the lifespan. Students completing this option are prepared to work with healthy individuals and clinical populations in a variety of settings. This option prepares students for positions in corporate, community, and clinical fitness settings. Some positions include: personal trainers, group exercise instructors, fitness managers, wellness coordinators, health educators, clinical exercise physiologists, and strength and conditioning coaches. It also prepares students for graduate school in clinical exercise physiology, public health, physical therapy, occupational therapy, and chiropractic school.
ScholarshipType: Merit-based, Need-based, or a combination of both

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Kinesiology, Option in Physical Education- Teacher Education
Department: College of Health and Human Services
Description: The Physical Education-Teacher Education Option (PE-T.E.) is designed for students who are interested in pursuing a career in teaching Physical Education in public and private schools (K-12). The program provides a pathway toward obtaining the California Single Subject Teaching Credential in Physical Education through its coursework and fieldwork experiences. The program includes subject matter preparation courses, professional education courses, fieldwork, and student teaching experiences necessary to develop expertise in teaching K-12 Physical Education. Upon successful completion of the PE-T.E. Option and passage of the CBEST and CSET examinations, students may apply to the credential program to receive their preliminary California Single Subject Teaching Credential in Physical Education. The PE-T.E. option is housed in the Department of Kinesiology, College of Health and Human Services.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Kinesiology, Option in Sport Psychology and Leadership
Requirements: Freshman applicants must meet the General University admission requirements. To be considered for admission, applicants must be a high school graduate (or equivalent), complete the required 15-unit college preparatory 'a-g' course pattern, and have a competitive 'college-qualifying' GPA. As CSULB and the Kinesiology major are impacted, meeting minimum requirements does not guarantee admission. Students are admitted into the 'Pre-Kinesiology' major and must complete major-specific declaration requirements to be admitted into the Sport Psychology and Leadership option.
Department: College of Health and Human Services
Description: The Sport Psychology and Leadership option is designed to prepare students for careers or graduate study in areas such as sport psychology, coaching, sport consulting, corporate wellness, health and fitness, personal training, and various leadership positions within sport organizations. Students gain knowledge in areas such as motor learning, performance enhancement, sport and exercise psychology, leadership, coaching, exercise physiology, biomechanics, and sport pedagogy. This option emphasizes the psychosocial and behavioral aspects of human movement across the lifespan, from diverse populations and settings.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Managerial Economics
Bachelor of Science in Marketing
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Marketing program at CSULB is designed to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of marketing principles and practices. Students learn how to analyze markets, develop marketing strategies, manage brands, conduct market research, and utilize digital marketing tools. The program prepares students for a wide range of careers in marketing, including brand management, market research, advertising, public relations, digital marketing, and sales. Students can choose from three emphasis areas to specialize their studies: Digital Marketing, Professional Selling and Sales Management, and General Marketing. This flexibility allows students to tailor their education to their specific career interests and goals. The curriculum combines theoretical knowledge with practical applications, often involving real-world projects and case studies, to ensure graduates are well-prepared for the dynamic marketing industry.
Accredidation: AACSB Accredited (College of Business)

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Materials Science
Department: College of Natural Sciences and Mathematics
Description: Materials science is a multidisciplinary field that combines chemistry, physics, and engineering to understand the fundamental properties, structure, and performance of materials. At CSULB, the Materials Science program offers a Bachelor of Science (BS) degree that prepares students for careers in industries such as aerospace, automotive, electronics, biomaterials, and energy. Our curriculum emphasizes hands-on learning, research opportunities, and collaborations with industry partners, providing students with practical skills and knowledge to address real-world challenges. Students in the Materials Science program will explore topics such as crystallography, thermodynamics, kinetics, mechanical properties, electrical properties, and optical properties of materials. They will learn to characterize, process, and design new materials with tailored properties for various applications. Our program also provides a strong foundation for graduate studies in materials science, engineering, or related fields.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Mathematics, Option in Applied Mathematics
Department: College of Natural Sciences and Mathematics
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Mathematics provides students with a strong foundation in mathematics, including concepts and applications, problem-solving skills, and the ability to communicate mathematical ideas effectively. This program prepares students for a variety of careers in industry, government, and education, as well as for graduate studies in mathematics or related fields. The Applied Mathematics option focuses on mathematical modeling, numerical analysis, optimization, and statistical methods, preparing students to apply mathematical techniques to solve real-world problems in science, engineering, business, and other areas.
ScholarshipType: President's Scholarships, College & Departmental Scholarships, Athletic Grants-in-Aid, External Scholarships

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Mathematics, Option in Applied Statistics
Requirements: Applicants must meet CSU minimum eligibility requirements. Admission to CSULB is competitive and based on a Multi-Factor Admission Score (MFAS) which considers factors including high school courses and grades. For this specific major (Mathematics, Applied Statistics Option, B.S.), applicants must have completed Pre-Calculus with a minimum grade of B.
Department: College of Natural Sciences and Mathematics
Description: The B.S. in Mathematics with an Option in Applied Statistics provides students with a solid mathematical foundation and specialized training in statistical theory and methods. This program prepares students for careers in fields that require statistical analysis and data interpretation, such as actuarial science, biomedical research, data science, market research, and quality control. Students develop critical thinking skills, problem-solving abilities, and expertise in statistical software and methodologies, making them highly competitive in today's data-driven world. The curriculum includes courses in probability, mathematical statistics, regression analysis, experimental design, and statistical computing. Graduates are well-prepared for entry-level positions in industry, government, and non-profit organizations, or for further graduate studies in statistics or related quantitative fields.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Mathematics, Option in Mathematics Education
Department: College of Natural Sciences and Mathematics
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Mathematics, Option in Mathematics Education is a comprehensive major that provides students with the mathematical depth and breadth necessary for a secondary mathematics teaching career. The program prepares students for the California Single Subject Credential in Mathematics and further graduate study in mathematics education. Students complete coursework in foundational mathematics, advanced mathematics topics, and mathematics education pedagogy. The curriculum emphasizes problem-solving, mathematical reasoning, and communication skills. The program also includes fieldwork experiences in secondary schools, allowing students to apply theoretical knowledge in practical settings. Graduates of the program are well-prepared to teach mathematics in middle schools and high schools, and to pursue leadership roles in mathematics education.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Mechanical Engineering
Description: Mechanical engineering is one of the broadest and oldest engineering disciplines. Mechanical engineers are involved in the design, analysis, and manufacturing of mechanical systems, often involving energy conversion and utilization. The Mechanical Engineering program at California State University, Long Beach is designed to provide students with a strong theoretical and practical background in these areas. The curriculum includes courses in mechanics, thermodynamics, fluid mechanics, heat transfer, materials science, manufacturing processes, and system design and control. Students gain hands-on experience through laboratory work and design projects, preparing them for a wide range of careers in industries such as aerospace, automotive, energy, robotics, and biomedical devices, or for further graduate studies.
Accredidation: Accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, http://www.abet.org.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Nursing
Requirements:
Admission to the Basic BSN program is highly competitive. Applicants are ranked based on the following admission criteria:
1. Prerequisite GPA (a minimum of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale is required)
2. Overall GPA (a minimum of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale is recommended)
3. ATI TEAS Exam (a minimum of 75% on the adjusted individual total score is required)
4. Local Admission Preference
5. Health-related work/volunteer experience
6. Bilingual proficiency

Prerequisite Courses: Human Anatomy (with lab), Human Physiology (with lab), General, Organic, and Biochemistry with Lab, Microbiology with Lab, Written Communication, Oral Communication, Critical Thinking, and Statistics.
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Nursing (BSN) program at California State University, Long Beach, prepares students for entry-level professional nursing practice. The curriculum integrates theoretical knowledge with clinical experience, emphasizing critical thinking, evidence-based practice, and cultural competence. Graduates are equipped to provide holistic care to diverse populations in various healthcare settings and are prepared for licensure as Registered Nurses (RNs). The School of Nursing offers two distinct pathways to obtain a BSN degree: a Pre-Licensure BSN track for students without a prior nursing license and an RN to BSN track for Associate Degree or Diploma prepared Registered Nurses. Each track is designed to meet the unique needs of its student population while upholding the highest standards of nursing education.
Accredidation: The Bachelor of Science in Nursing (BSN) program at California State University, Long Beach, is accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education (CCNE), 655 K Street NW, Suite 750, Washington, DC 20001, 202-887-6791. The program is also approved by the California Board of Registered Nursing (BRN).
ScholarshipAmount: Varies, from $100 to full cost of attendance

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Nutrition and Dietetics
Description: The undergraduate program in Nutrition and Dietetics provides comprehensive instruction in food, nutrition, and food service systems. It is approved by the Accreditation Council for Education in Nutrition and Dietetics (ACEND) of the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics as a Didactic Program in Dietetics (DPD).
Accredidation: Approved by the Accreditation Council for Education in Nutrition and Dietetics (ACEND) of the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics as a Didactic Program in Dietetics (DPD).
ScholarshipType: University, College, Department, and External scholarships

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Operations and Supply Chain Management
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Business Administration - Operations and Supply Chain Management (OSCM) prepares students to be effective and responsible professionals in a wide range of careers including supply chain management, logistics, quality management, project management, operations management, procurement, and consulting. The program emphasizes decision making, problem-solving, and continuous improvement through an innovative curriculum that integrates both theoretical knowledge and practical skills. Students develop strong analytical and quantitative skills using relevant software tools.
Accredidation: Accredited by AACSB International (the premier global accrediting body for business schools).

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Physics, Option in Materials Science
Department: College of Natural Sciences and Mathematics
Description: Our Department of Physics and Astronomy offers a B.S. in Physics with an Option in Materials Science. The Materials Science option focuses on the structure, properties, processing, and performance of materials, preparing students for careers in materials-related industries or for graduate study in materials science and engineering. Students will develop a strong foundation in physics while also gaining specialized knowledge in the science of materials.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Recreation Therapy
Requirements:
To be admitted to the Recreation Therapy major, students must meet the following requirements:
1. Completion of a minimum of 40 units.
2. Completion of the following courses (or their equivalents) with a grade of “C” or better: RLS 101, RLS 210, RLS 225, RLS 235.
3. Completion of the following courses (or their equivalents) with a grade of “C” or better: ENGL 100 or GE A1, Oral Communication GE A2, Critical Thinking GE A3, and Mathematics/Quantitative Reasoning GE B2.
4. A minimum cumulative GPA of 2.5.
5. Submission of an application to the Recreation and Leisure Studies Department office.
Department: College of Health and Human Services
Description: Recreation Therapy (RT) is a systematic process that utilizes recreation and other activity-based interventions to address the assessed needs of individuals with illnesses and/or disabling conditions, as a means to psychological and physical health, recovery and well-being. The purpose of the Bachelor of Science (BS) in Recreation Therapy program at California State University, Long Beach (CSULB) is to prepare students with the foundational knowledge and practical skills necessary to provide recreation therapy services across the continuum of care. The program aims to prepare students to successfully pass the national certification exam to become a Certified Therapeutic Recreation Specialist (CTRS) upon completion of the program, including practicum and internship experiences.
ScholarshipType: Merit-based, Need-based, Departmental, Area of study-specific

ProgramName: Minor in Africana Studies
Minor in American Sign Language Deaf Cultures
Requirements:
This minor requires the completion of 18 units, of which a minimum of 9 units must be upper-division. A grade of “C” or better must be achieved in all courses taken to complete the minor.

Required Courses (15 units):
ASL 101 American Sign Language I (4)
ASL 102 American Sign Language II (4)
ASL 201 American Sign Language III (4)
ASLD 300 Introduction to Deaf Cultures (3)

In addition to the required courses, students must complete at least 3 units of upper-division coursework from the following list:
ASLD 310 American Deaf History (3)
ASLD 320 Deaf Literature, Film, and Arts (3)
ASLD 330 Deaf People and Social Justice (3)
ASLD 450 Senior Seminar in Deaf Studies (3)
LING 425 Education and Deafness (3)
Description: The minor in American Sign Language and Deaf Cultures provides students with an understanding of American Sign Language (ASL) linguistics and its cultural applications within the Deaf community. This minor provides an understanding of Deaf individuals and the impact of deafness from a historical and societal perspective. Through study, students will acquire proficiency in ASL and learn about Deaf Culture, Deaf history, and the politics of Deafness. Students will learn the social, educational, and political ramifications of being Deaf within a hearing society. This minor prepares students for careers working with Deaf individuals and the organizations that serve them. It also provides a strong foundation for students interested in pursuing graduate studies in Deaf education, interpreting, audiology, linguistics, or related fields.
ScholarshipType: Academic achievement, community service, leadership, and financial need

ProgramName: Minor in American Studies
Description: The American Studies Minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a broad knowledge of the social, political, cultural, and economic forces shaping the American experience. Students take courses offered by participating departments in American Studies which include Anthropology, Art History, Black Studies, Chicano and Latino Studies, English, History, Journalism and Mass Communication, Political Science, Religious Studies, and Women’s, Gender, and Sexuality Studies. The program provides students with a multidisciplinary perspective to analyze complex issues within American society. Courses for the American Studies minor satisfy General Education requirements. Some major restrictions may apply.

ProgramName: Minor in Anthropology
Description: A minor in anthropology provides students with an integrated understanding of humanity that is grounded in the methods and theories of anthropology's four subfields. The minor allows students to pursue their interests in anthropology, supplementing their major with an anthropological perspective on the world. The minor requires a total of 18 units, consisting of 6 units of required coursework and 12 units of elective coursework.

ProgramName: Minor in Asian & Asian American Studies
Description: A minor in Asian American Studies is excellent for those who wish to develop skills and knowledge in an interdisciplinary field that helps them understand the historical and contemporary experiences of Asian Americans. This program supports your major by providing coursework that will challenge you to think critically about race, ethnicity, immigration, gender, class, and sexuality within both American and global contexts. You will also develop a deeper understanding of the diverse communities of Asian Americans, explore issues of social justice, and enhance your awareness of the unique challenges and contributions of Asian Americans. The minor will provide you with analytical and critical thinking skills that can be applied to a variety of careers and post-graduate studies.
ScholarshipAmount: Awards range from $100 to $10,000 per year
ScholarshipType: Merit-based, financial need, community service, departmental, private, and university-wide

ProgramName: Minor in Business Administration
Requirements:
To be considered for admission to the Business Administration Minor, students must meet the following minimum requirements: 
1. Complete with a grade of "C" or better: ACCT 201, ECON 101 or ECON 100.
2. A minimum CSULB GPA of 2.5.
3. Be in good academic standing.
4. Completed at least 45 units.

Meeting the minimum requirements does not guarantee admission into the Business Administration Minor program. The College of Business is an impacted college and admission into the Business Administration Minor program is very competitive.
Description: The Minor in Business Administration provides students from outside the College of Business a basic understanding of business disciplines that will complement their major. Students will develop a foundational understanding of various business functions, including accounting, finance, marketing, management, and information systems. This minor will provide students with practical skills that can be applied in various professional settings, enhancing their career prospects. The Business Administration Minor requires 24 units.

ProgramName: Minor in Cambodian (Khmer)
Description: The minor in Cambodian (Khmer) is designed for students who are interested in Cambodian language, literature, and culture. The minor requires a minimum of 18 units of coursework, including 9 units of Cambodian language courses and 9 units of Cambodian culture courses. Students will have the opportunity to study a range of topics, including Cambodian history, politics, religion, arts, and society. The minor is interdisciplinary and draws on courses from various departments, including Asian and Asian American Studies, History, Political Science, Religious Studies, and Art. The minor is open to all students, regardless of their major, and can be completed in conjunction with any bachelor's degree program.

ProgramName: Minor in Chicano & Latino Studies
Requirements:
A minimum of 18 units is required. At least 12 of the 18 units must be upper-division.

Take the following two courses:
CHLS 100 - Introduction to Chicano and Latino Studies (3 units)
CHLS 300 - Chicano and Latino History (3 units)

Take 12 units of CHLS electives of which 9 units must be upper-division.
Description: The minor in Chicano and Latino Studies is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a comprehensive knowledge of the Chicano and Latino experience, including the history, culture, politics, and social issues impacting these communities. The minor complements a wide variety of majors, providing students with critical perspectives and analytical skills relevant to an increasingly diverse society.

ProgramName: Minor in Chinese Language & Culture
Description: The Chinese Language and Culture Minor aims to provide students with comprehensive knowledge of Chinese language, history, and culture. The minor requires a minimum of 18 units, of which 6 units are required courses and 12 units are elective courses. The program offers students an opportunity to develop an understanding of China's rich cultural heritage and its contemporary society. Students will develop proficiency in Chinese language and enhance their cross-cultural communication skills. This minor is an excellent complement to a variety of majors, including International Studies, Business Administration, Political Science, and History.

ProgramName: Minor in Classical Studies
Requirements: Students interested in declaring this minor should see the department's undergraduate advisor. The minor requires a total of 18 units. These units must include 9 upper-division units. No more than 6 units can be taken from any single department other than Classics.
Description: The minor in Classical Studies offers students the opportunity to learn about the ancient Mediterranean world through a study of its history, literature, philosophy, languages, and material culture. The minor offers students the opportunity to develop skills in critical thinking and analysis, research, and communication. It prepares students for a variety of careers in fields such as education, law, journalism, public service, and the arts, or for graduate work in ancient history, archaeology, classical languages and literature, and related fields. The minor combines courses from a variety of disciplines, including Art History, Comparative World Literature, Greek, History, Latin, and Philosophy. It is an excellent complement to majors in those disciplines, as well as to majors in English, Film and Electronic Arts, Journalism, Liberal Studies, Political Science, Religious Studies, and Women’s, Gender, and Sexuality Studies.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies, with some awards such as the Annette L. Demaria Scholarship at $1,000.

ProgramName: Minor in Communication Studies
Minor in Comparative World Literature
Requirements:
The Minor in Comparative World Literature is available to any non-major. It requires completion of 18 units, distributed as follows:
1. Take one of the following courses (3 units): CWL 100, CWL 101, CWL 210.
2. Take 15 units of upper-division coursework in CWL.

No more than 6 units of this coursework may be from courses taken outside the department (approved by the CWL undergraduate advisor). At least 6 units must be from courses that deal primarily with non-Western and/or non-canonical literatures (approved by the CWL undergraduate advisor). A minimum of 9 units must be taken in residence at CSULB.

All courses in the minor must be passed with a grade of “C” or better. The minor must be completed with a minimum GPA of 2.0. A course may not be used to satisfy both major and minor requirements.
Description: Comparative World Literature is an interdisciplinary field involving the study of literature across national and linguistic boundaries. Students in the minor learn how to analyze the diverse aspects of world literatures, including the historical, political, social, and aesthetic characteristics of texts from various cultural contexts. This minor is for students who want to develop a broad knowledge of literature while also developing critical thinking and writing skills.

ProgramName: Minor in Criminal Justice
Department: School of Criminology, Criminal Justice, and Emergency Management
Description:
The Minor in Criminal Justice is designed for students interested in a focused study of the criminal justice system and related topics. This minor complements a wide range of majors, providing students with a foundational understanding of various components such as law enforcement, courts, corrections, and theories of crime and deviance. It is ideal for students considering careers in law enforcement, legal fields, social work, public policy, or further graduate studies in criminology and criminal justice.
Students pursuing this minor will explore the complexities of criminal behavior, the societal responses to crime, and the ethical dilemmas inherent in the justice system. The curriculum emphasizes critical thinking, analytical skills, and an interdisciplinary approach to understanding crime and justice issues. Through core courses and electives, students will gain insights into the historical development, current practices, and future challenges of the criminal justice field.

ProgramName: Minor in Economics
Requirements: This minor is available to any non-pre-economics, non-economics, and non-business economics major. To declare the Economics minor, students must be in good academic standing (2.0 overall GPA). Requirements include: ECON 100, ECON 101, and twelve units of upper-division Economics courses selected with the approval of an Economics Department undergraduate advisor. At least six of these twelve units must be from 400-level courses.

ProgramName: Minor in English Creative Writing
Requirements:
The Creative Writing Minor requires 21 units.

Take two of the following introductory courses (6 units):
* ENGL 205 - Introduction to Creative Writing
* ENGL 206 - Introduction to Creative Writing: Poetry
* ENGL 207 - Introduction to Creative Writing: Fiction

Take four of the following intermediate/advanced courses (12 units):
* ENGL 305 - Intermediate Creative Writing
* ENGL 306 - Intermediate Creative Writing: Poetry
* ENGL 307 - Intermediate Creative Writing: Fiction
* ENGL 405 - Advanced Creative Writing
* ENGL 406 - Advanced Creative Writing: Poetry
* ENGL 407 - Advanced Creative Writing: Fiction
* ENGL 408 - Creative Writing: The Short Story
* ENGL 409 - The Writer’s Profession
* ENGL 458 - Creative Non-Fiction

At least two of these courses must be at the 400 level.

Take one of the following literature courses (3 units):
* ENGL 363 - Poetry and Poetics
* ENGL 380 - Approaches to English Studies
* ENGL 465 - Modern and Contemporary American Literature
* ENGL 467 - Studies in a Major American Writer
* ENGL 475 - Studies in a Major British Writer
* ENGL 487 - Contemporary Literature
Description: A Minor in Creative Writing consists of 24 units in English. This minor supports the development of students' writing abilities in fiction, poetry, and/or creative nonfiction.
