Students will also gain a deeper understanding of literary forms and strategies as a writer and reader. Students apply to the minor only after completing the 6 units of lower division coursework and ENGL 302: Introduction to Creative Writing. Successful applicants will submit a writing sample demonstrating strong potential in their area of emphasis.

ProgramName: Minor in English Literature
Requirements: To declare a Minor in Literature, students must schedule an advising appointment with the undergraduate advisor. The minor requires a total of 18 units. This includes 6 units of required courses (ENGL 380 and ENGL 497) and 12 units of elective literature courses.
Description: The English Minor is a program of 18 units of English courses beyond the General Education requirements. The Minor is intended for students in other majors who wish to develop their skills in literary analysis, critical writing, and creative expression. The Minor in English is highly flexible, allowing students to choose six courses from the full range of English offerings. Students can satisfy personal interests while developing knowledge and skills in literary studies, rhetoric and composition, creative writing, or TESOL. A total of nine upper-division units is required.

ProgramName: Minor in English Rhetoric & Composition
Description: The Rhetoric and Composition minor provides students with the opportunity to take advanced coursework in rhetoric, composition, and writing instruction. Students learn to analyze texts and arguments; identify rhetorical strategies; and write effectively in a variety of rhetorical situations and genres. In addition, students interested in careers in writing and publishing, or in becoming high school English teachers, have an opportunity to gain experience in teaching writing, tutoring, and/or working in a university writing center. The minor complements a wide variety of majors.

ProgramName: Minor in English Special Emphasis
Requirements:
This minor allows a student to create a program of study (12 units of upper-division English courses) in consultation with the undergraduate advisor. These courses must be selected from 300- and 400-level English courses, and must constitute a coherent program.

Prerequisites: Successful completion of the G.E. foundation courses.

Requirements:
1. A minimum of 18 units of English courses.
2. A minimum of 12 of the 18 units must be upper-division.
3. Students must achieve a "C" or better in all courses required for the minor.
ScholarshipType: Merit-based, need-based, leadership, and community service

ProgramName: Minor in Environmental Science & Policy
Description: Environmental Science and Policy (ESP) is an interdisciplinary field that addresses the complex interactions between human societies and the natural environment. The ESP minor will prepare students to understand the scientific basis of environmental problems, as well as the social, economic, and political aspects of environmental issues and policy solutions. The minor provides students with a foundational understanding of environmental science, environmental policy, and research methods in ESP. Students will gain critical thinking skills, problem-solving abilities, and an appreciation for diverse perspectives on environmental issues. This minor complements a wide range of majors, providing valuable knowledge and skills for careers in environmental consulting, natural resource management, policy analysis, advocacy, and education.

ProgramName: Minor in European Studies
Description: The Minor in European Studies offers an interdisciplinary approach to the study of Europe. By emphasizing the study of European languages, literatures, cultures, history, politics, economics, and geography, the Minor provides students with a broad exposure to European civilization and its global impact. It offers a variety of courses and topics that reflect the broad interests and expertise of CSULB faculty. Students will acquire valuable analytical and research skills and develop an in-depth understanding of Europe.

ProgramName: Minor in Event Planning and Management
Requirements: Students wishing to declare the minor must be in good academic standing (2.0 GPA) and should meet with the minor advisor. To declare the Minor in Event Planning and Management, please complete the Request to Add Minor form and send to the department office and minor advisor.
Description: The Minor in Event Planning and Management will provide students with the interdisciplinary knowledge and skills needed to design, plan, implement, and evaluate events in a range of industries. The minor is offered to provide an academic credential in event planning and management that will enhance the marketability of graduates, and provide continuing education to individuals currently working in the field of event planning and management. Students will learn the various aspects of the planning and implementation process of different events, including but not limited to, sports, recreation, tourism, entertainment, and social. Students will gain knowledge in event leadership, marketing, sponsorship, risk management, financial practices, and customer service. Additionally, students will engage in an experiential learning opportunity in event planning, implementation, and evaluation.

ProgramName: Minor in Family and Consumer Sciences, Fashion Design
Department: College of Health and Human Services

ProgramName: Minor in Family and Consumer Sciences, Fashion Merchandising
Department: College of Health and Human Services
Description: The Fashion Merchandising Minor provides students with an understanding of the product development, production, distribution, and marketing of fashion goods. The minor provides students with professional skills and knowledge required for positions in the fashion industry and prepares them for graduate studies.

ProgramName: Minor in Family and Consumer Sciences, Textiles
Description: The Textiles Minor offers an interdisciplinary approach to the study of textile materials and their application to apparel, home furnishings, and related industries. The curriculum provides students with a strong foundation in textile science, including fiber properties, yarn and fabric construction, textile finishes, and coloration. Students also gain an understanding of textile economics, sustainability, and global sourcing. The minor prepares students for careers in textile product development, quality control, merchandising, and entrepreneurship.

ProgramName: Minor in Food Science
Requirements:
To be eligible for the minor in food science, students must complete a minimum of 18 units in food science, 9 of which must be upper division.

Required Courses (12 units):
NFS 211 - Food Science (3 units)
NFS 311 - Food Product Development (3 units)
NFS 411 - Food Analysis (3 units)
NFS 412 - Food Processing and Preservation (3 units)

Take three to five units from the following:
NFS 492A, NFS 492C, NFS 497, NFS 499.
Description: The Minor in Food Science is a multidisciplinary program designed to enhance the knowledge and skills of students who are interested in the application of science and engineering principles to the study of food. It covers a broad range of topics including food chemistry, microbiology, processing, safety, and nutrition. This minor is suitable for students in various majors such as Biology, Chemistry, Engineering, Health Science, and other related fields who wish to gain expertise in the food industry. Graduates with a Minor in Food Science will be well-prepared for entry-level positions in food research and development, quality assurance, regulatory affairs, and food production, or for further graduate studies in food science or related areas.

ProgramName: Minor in Forensic Studies
Requirements: The minor in Forensic Studies is available to any student in good standing.
Department: School of Criminology, Criminal Justice, and Emergency Management
Description: The undergraduate Minor in Forensic Studies is housed in the College of Liberal Arts and administered through the Department of Criminal Justice. The minor is designed to provide students with an interdisciplinary understanding of forensic evidence in a variety of contexts, including criminal investigations, medical-legal contexts, and civil disputes. The minor allows students to apply forensic knowledge to a wide range of academic fields, including the natural sciences, social sciences, and humanities. The minor is an ideal complement to a variety of majors, including criminal justice, psychology, biology, chemistry, anthropology, and sociology. The minor requires 18 units of coursework, including 6 units of core courses and 12 units of electives. Students must complete a minimum of 9 units in residence at CSULB. All courses counting toward the minor must be completed with a grade of "C" or better.
CostPerCredit: $420 per unit (Non-Resident fee, in addition to basic tuition & fees)

ProgramName: Minor in French & Francophone Studies
Requirements: A minimum of 20 units are required for the Minor in French and Francophone Studies, 11 of which must be at the upper-division level. A grade of “C” or better must be achieved in all courses applied to the minor.
Description: The French & Francophone Studies program offers both a B.A. and a Minor in French & Francophone Studies. Our curriculum is designed to provide students with a solid foundation in French language proficiency and a comprehensive understanding of French and Francophone cultures, literatures, and societies. Through a diverse range of courses, students develop critical thinking skills, cultural competence, and effective communication abilities. Our program emphasizes interdisciplinary approaches, encouraging students to explore the intersections of language, history, politics, and the arts. Additionally, we offer opportunities for study abroad, internships, and engagement with the vibrant French-speaking communities both locally and internationally.
ScholarshipType: Merit-based, need-based, leadership, community service, talent-based

ProgramName: Minor in Geographic Information Science
Description: The Geographic Information Science (GIScience) Minor provides students with knowledge and skills in geospatial technologies. These technologies are used to collect, manage, analyze, and visualize data that is referenced to locations on Earth's surface. GIScience is highly interdisciplinary and provides skills that are applicable to a wide range of academic disciplines and career fields including anthropology, biology, criminal justice, environmental science, geology, health sciences, public administration, and urban studies. The minor also prepares students for the GIS Professional (GISP) certification. Students will be able to apply spatial reasoning and use GIS software for data acquisition, management, analysis, and visualization of spatial data.

ProgramName: Minor in Geography
Requirements: To declare the Geography minor, please see one of the undergraduate advisors.
Description: A Minor in Geography will complement many majors including those in the natural sciences, social sciences, and humanities, as well as business and engineering. The Minor in Geography will allow you to learn more about geographic concepts, data collection and analysis, and interpretation of geographic information, as well as gaining skills relevant to careers in many fields.

ProgramName: Minor in German
Description: A minor in German provides students with a foundational understanding of the German language and culture. Through a combination of language courses, literature, and cultural studies, students will develop proficiency in German communication skills while gaining insights into the diverse cultures of German-speaking countries. This minor complements various majors, offering valuable cross-cultural perspectives and enhancing career opportunities in fields such as international relations, business, education, and the arts. Students pursuing a minor in German will acquire: Proficiency in German language skills (reading, writing, listening, speaking). Knowledge of German literature, history, and cultural traditions. Intercultural competence and critical thinking skills. An appreciation for the diversity of German-speaking cultures.
CostPerCredit: $425 (non-resident fee per unit) + basic tuition fees

ProgramName: Minor in Gerontology
Requirements:
The Minor in Gerontology consists of a minimum of 18 units, 9 of which must be at the upper-division level. Students must select courses from at least three different disciplines.

Required Course (3 units):
GERN 400. Perspectives on Gerontology (3).
Prerequisite: Upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

Electives (15 units):
Select 15 units from the following list with at least three different disciplines represented. A minimum of 6 units must be at the 400-level.

Other courses may be used as electives with the prior approval of the Gerontology Program Minor Advisor.
Department: College of Health and Human Services
Description: The Gerontology Minor offers an interdisciplinary approach to the study of aging. The program is designed to provide students with a broad understanding of the social, psychological, and biological aspects of aging, as well as the societal implications of an aging population. Students will gain knowledge and skills relevant to working with older adults in various capacities, including healthcare, social services, policy, and research. The minor is suitable for students from a wide range of majors who are interested in enhancing their understanding of aging and preparing for careers that involve older adult populations. Our curriculum emphasizes critical thinking, ethical considerations, and culturally sensitive practices in gerontology.

ProgramName: Minor in Global Migration Studies
Requirements: The minor in Global Migration Studies is open to all students. Requirements are a minimum of 18 units to include GMS 200, and 15 units of electives chosen from the following list. At least nine of the 15 elective units must be at the upper-division level (300- or 400-level). A course can only be used to satisfy one category of the minor requirements.
Description: The Minor in Global Migration Studies provides students with an interdisciplinary understanding of the causes, dynamics, and consequences of human migration in an increasingly globalized world. Through an interdisciplinary curriculum drawing on the social sciences and humanities, students will develop critical thinking skills and a nuanced perspective on migration issues, preparing them for careers in fields such as social justice, human rights, policy analysis, and international development.

ProgramName: Minor in Global Middle Eastern Studies
Requirements: The minor in Global Middle Eastern Studies consists of a total of 18 units with at least a 2.0 GPA. At least 12 units must be upper division. It includes 6 units of required courses (GMES 100 and GMES 400) and 12 units of electives chosen from specified categories.
Description: The Global Middle Eastern Studies (GMES) Minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a multi-faceted understanding of the Middle East and its relationship to global issues and processes. Our goal is to provide students with the necessary knowledge and analytical tools to understand the complexity and diversity of the region and its people. This minor provides a foundational understanding of the history, politics, cultures, and languages of the Middle East from an interdisciplinary perspective. This minor is open to all majors and will be especially useful for students interested in careers in international relations, journalism, diplomacy, and the non-profit sector. It will also prepare students for graduate work in Middle Eastern Studies and related fields. The minor combines coursework in Middle Eastern Languages (Arabic and/or Persian), History, Political Science, Religious Studies, Geography, and International Studies.
Accredidation: Western Association of Schools and Colleges (WASC) Senior College and University Commission (WSCUC)

ProgramName: Minor in Greek
Description: Ancient Greek is a classical language that is part of the Indo-European family. Knowledge of Ancient Greek is vital for understanding the origins and meanings of many English words as well as the history of Western philosophy, literature, and culture. The Greek minor at CSULB introduces students to the Greek language and texts and provides the skills for further study of Ancient Greece. The program consists of three levels of Ancient Greek language courses (GREE 101, 102, and 201), two courses in Greek literature in translation (CLSC 315 and 316), and one elective course chosen from Greek-related courses in Classics or other departments. Students who complete the minor will gain proficiency in reading Ancient Greek and an appreciation for the enduring legacy of Ancient Greek civilization.

ProgramName: Minor in Health Humanities
Requirements: To declare the Minor in Health Humanities, a student must have an overall GPA of at least 2.0. To graduate with the Minor in Health Humanities, a student must have a GPA of at least 2.0 in the minor. The Minor requires 18 units, consisting of 6 units of required courses and 12 units of electives.
Description: The Health Humanities Minor provides students with the critical skills needed to understand the complexity of health, illness, healthcare, and medicine by drawing on resources from the humanities (including philosophy, ethics, literature, history, religious studies, and art history) and the arts (visual arts, performance arts, and creative writing). The minor will prepare students for a range of health-related careers and fields, including medical school, nursing, pharmacy, public health, social work, and many other allied health professions. It will also prepare students for graduate work in the health humanities, medical ethics, public health, and related fields. In addition, it provides a strong foundation for a variety of other careers, including law, education, business, journalism, government, and policy.

ProgramName: Minor in Health Science
Department: College of Health and Human Services
Description: The minor in Health Science provides students with the opportunity to gain expertise in the field of Health Science and complements a variety of majors. Students completing the minor will learn about population health, health disparities, health promotion, disease prevention, and public health policies and issues.

ProgramName: Minor in History
Requirements: This minor is open to all students with a GPA of 2.0 or better. A minimum of 18 units in history, including at least 9 upper-division units. Six of the upper-division units must be from 400-level courses. HIST 301 is a prerequisite for all 400-level courses.
ScholarshipType: University-wide scholarships, College/Department scholarships, Athletic scholarships

ProgramName: Minor in Human Development
Department: College of Health and Human Services
Description: The Human Development minor is a multidisciplinary program that allows students to study the physical, social, emotional, and cognitive development of individuals from conception through old age within diverse contexts. It is ideal for students who wish to augment their major with knowledge of individual and family development. The minor provides a strong foundation for a variety of careers in fields such as social work, education, counseling, health care, and other human services. Students interested in the minor should consult with a Human Development advisor.

ProgramName: Minor in International Economics
Description: The International Economics Minor is designed to give students a systematic exposure to the subject area of international economics. The minor consists of 21 units (7 courses) and covers areas such as international trade, international finance, economic development, and international economic policy issues. The minor requires a minimum of 9 units of upper division economics courses.
ScholarshipType: Merit-based, Need-based, Major-specific, Leadership, Community Service

ProgramName: Minor in International Studies
Requirements: The Minor in International Studies consists of 18 units, 12 of which must be at the upper-division level. Students must maintain an overall GPA of 2.5 in the minor. A maximum of 6 units of transfer credits may be applied to the minor. All courses in the minor must be passed with a grade of “C” or better. Students must also complete the capstone course I/ST 491 with a grade of “C” or better. Students pursuing a major in International Studies are not eligible for the minor. The minor must be completed concurrently with a baccalaureate degree. The minor is not available to students who have already completed a baccalaureate degree.
Description: The International Studies Minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a deeper understanding of issues that transcend national boundaries, such as economics, politics, environment, and culture. The minor examines global interdependence and processes of change, focusing on the historical and contemporary relationships between developed and developing countries. Through an interdisciplinary approach, students will gain a critical perspective on the forces shaping the global community.

ProgramName: Minor in Italian
Description: The Minor in Italian is an 18-unit program that provides students with the linguistic and cultural skills necessary to be successful in an increasingly global world. Students will engage with historical, literary, and contemporary texts, honing their analytical, written, and oral communication skills in Italian. Students will learn about Italian culture and society in a global context through a variety of course offerings covering literature, cinema, and cultural production. This minor can be paired with any major and is valuable for students interested in a wide range of careers.

ProgramName: Minor in Japanese Language and Culture
Requirements: To declare the Minor in Japanese Language and Culture, students must first complete JAPN 102 (or its equivalent) with a C or better. Next, students must fill out the ‘Request to Add Minor/Certificate’ form. Students will then need to meet with the Japanese Language Program Coordinator or an AAAS Department Advisor to review their request and sign the form. The Minor consists of a minimum of 20 units, including specific lower and upper division coursework.
Description: The Minor in Japanese Language and Culture offers students an exciting opportunity to complement their major studies with a focused introduction to the Japanese language and its rich culture. The program is designed to provide students with foundational proficiency in the Japanese language, enabling them to communicate effectively in various everyday contexts. Beyond language acquisition, the minor delves into the diverse aspects of Japanese culture, including its history, literature, arts, and societal structures, fostering a comprehensive understanding of Japan's unique heritage. Through a blend of language courses and cultural studies, students will develop critical thinking skills and cross-cultural competencies essential for engaging with a globalized world. Whether students are interested in international business, education, tourism, or simply wish to broaden their cultural horizons, the Minor in Japanese Language and Culture equips them with valuable insights and practical skills to navigate and appreciate Japanese society and its global impact.
ScholarshipType: Academic achievement, financial need, campus/community activities, work experience, and other personal characteristics and experiences.

ProgramName: Minor in Jewish Studies
Minor in Journalism
Requirements: The Minor in Journalism consists of 18 units, 12 of which must be at the upper-division level. A minimum of 6 units must be unique to the minor (not double-counted with a major or other minor). All courses in the minor must be completed with a grade of "C" or better. The minor is not available to Journalism majors.

ProgramName: Minor in Korean Language and Culture
Description: The minor in Korean Language and Culture provides students with a solid foundation in the Korean language and culture. Through a combination of rigorous language training and in-depth cultural studies, students develop proficiency in all aspects of the Korean language (listening, speaking, reading, and writing), as well as a comprehensive understanding of Korean society, history, literature, and contemporary culture. The program aims to foster intercultural competence and prepare students for various career paths that require expertise in Korean language and culture, such as international relations, business, education, and translation.

ProgramName: Minor in Latin American Studies
Description: The Latin American Studies (LAS) program at California State University, Long Beach offers an interdisciplinary Minor for undergraduate students across the university. The program introduces students to the culture, history, and political economy of Latin America and the Caribbean from a variety of disciplinary perspectives. As an interdisciplinary program, LAS offers a wide range of courses and topics, including Latin American film, indigenous cultures, gender, immigration, human rights, environmental issues, history of conquest and resistance, US-Latin American relations, and contemporary politics. Students in the program develop a global understanding of social justice, cultural diversity, and human interactions by exploring the region through a variety of disciplinary lenses, including Anthropology, Art History, Chicano & Latino Studies, Communication Studies, Comparative World Literature, Economics, Geography, History, Journalism, Political Science, Portuguese, Religious Studies, and Spanish.

ProgramName: Minor in Latin
Requirements: The Minor in Latin requires 19 units. At least 12 of these units must be upper-division. Coursework must be completed with a grade of “C” or better. To declare the Minor in Latin, students must make an appointment with the Department’s Undergraduate Advisor.

ProgramName: Minor in Linguistics
Minor in Linguistics TESOL
Description: The Minor in Linguistics TESOL (Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages) provides students with knowledge and skills for teaching English as a second or foreign language. The program gives students a solid foundation in descriptive linguistics (phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, and semantics) and sociolinguistics. The program also provides knowledge and practical training in ESL methodologies, curriculum development, and language assessment. The minor is a practical program for students considering teaching English abroad or pursuing graduate studies in TESOL. Students interested in the minor should consult an advisor in the Department of Linguistics to discuss courses and career options. A cumulative GPA of 2.0 is required in all courses applicable to the minor.

ProgramName: Minor in Medieval & Renaissance Studies
Requirements: To declare the Minor, a student must be in good academic standing and should file a 'Request to Declare a Minor' form with the Coordinator of the Program in Medieval and Renaissance Studies.
Description: The Center for Medieval and Renaissance Studies (CMARS) offers an interdisciplinary minor in Medieval and Renaissance Studies. This minor allows students to explore the history, literatures, arts, religions, and cultures of Europe and the Mediterranean from the late Roman Empire (ca. 300 CE) to the mid-seventeenth century. It offers an opportunity for students in a wide variety of majors, including Art, Comparative World Literature, English, History, Philosophy, and Religious Studies, to study the premodern past in depth. The interdisciplinary nature of the minor also enables students to investigate the historical, literary, and cultural developments of the premodern world from multiple perspectives. Students who complete the minor will have an excellent foundation for graduate study in any of the participating disciplines. The Minor requires completion of 18 units of coursework drawn from an approved list of courses in the Departments of Art, Comparative World Literature, English, History, Philosophy, and Religious Studies. To see the specific requirements for the Minor in Medieval and Renaissance Studies, please see the Academic Catalog.
CostPerCredit: $420 per unit for non-residents (in addition to standard tuition and fees)

ProgramName: Minor in Native American Cultures
Requirements: This minor is open to all students.
Description: The Minor in Native American Cultures focuses on the study of Native American experiences, histories, cultures, and contemporary issues. It is an interdisciplinary minor designed for students interested in a broad understanding of the Indigenous peoples of the Americas. Students will explore diverse perspectives, critical methodologies, and the impact of colonialism, sovereignty, and self-determination movements. The curriculum emphasizes the rich cultural heritage, resilience, and ongoing contributions of Native American communities. Through a combination of coursework from various departments, students will develop a nuanced understanding of Native American cultures and their significance in global contexts, preparing them for careers in education, public service, non-profit organizations, and further academic study.

ProgramName: Minor in Philosophy
Requirements: A minor is not a program that students apply to for admission to the university. Students must first be admitted to a degree-granting major program at CSULB. Once enrolled, students wishing to minor in Philosophy must contact the department for advisement.
Description: The Philosophy Department offers a Minor in Philosophy. The minor offers students in other majors the opportunity to explore the philosophical foundations of their own major and to acquire competence in philosophical analysis, critical thinking, ethical reasoning, and historical, social, and political thought. The minor also helps students prepare for graduate or professional studies in fields such as law, government, journalism, business, education, and public policy. The minor is flexible, allowing students to tailor it to suit their own interests. It also has specific requirements to assure that students acquire a good foundation in Philosophy, including a course in Logic, and at least two courses at the 300- or 400-level. For more details on the Minor in Philosophy, please see the University Catalog.

ProgramName: Minor in Political Science
Requirements: To add the Political Science minor, please see the undergraduate advisor during their drop-in hours or schedule an appointment. You must bring a completed Request to Add or Change Major/Minor form with you.

ProgramName: Minor in Psychology
Requirements: The minor in Psychology is available to any student not majoring in Psychology. It consists of a minimum of 23 units, at least 12 of which must be upper division. Students interested in the minor in Psychology should contact the Psychology Undergraduate Advising Office (PSY Room 205) for advising and to declare the minor.
Description: The Psychology minor is designed for students who want to augment their major with knowledge about human behavior. The minor will allow students to apply psychological principles to their major field of study, and to provide skills in critical thinking, research, and communication.

ProgramName: Minor in Public Administration
Description: The Minor in Public Administration is designed to give students in other majors an opportunity to acquire a basic understanding of public sector organizations and their management, to prepare them for entry level positions in government and non-profit organizations, or to enhance their career prospects if they choose to pursue a graduate degree in public administration. The minor offers students an introduction to the theoretical and practical dimensions of public administration through required coursework, and allows them to gain additional understanding of the field through a variety of elective choices.

ProgramName: Minor in Public Policy Interdisciplinary
Description: The minor in Public Policy Interdisciplinary focuses on policy analysis and the political processes and institutions that shape public policy. Students will learn how public policy is made, the factors that shape policy decisions, and how to analyze the consequences of policy choices. The minor will help prepare students for careers in government, non-profit organizations, and private sector roles involving policy analysis, advocacy, and public affairs. It will also provide a strong foundation for graduate studies in public policy, public administration, law, or related fields.

ProgramName: Minor in Public Relations
Description: A minor in Public Relations provides students with an understanding of the theory and principles of public relations, along with training in strategic communication, writing, and message development, research and evaluation, and crisis communication. The Public Relations minor can be a useful complement to a variety of majors including Business, Journalism, Psychology, Communication Studies, Political Science, and others.

ProgramName: Minor in Queer Studies
Description: The Queer Studies Minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to introduce students to the field of Queer Studies, including LGBTQ history, activism, politics, and culture. Courses in the minor focus on understanding the social construction of sexuality, gender, race, class, and nation; the dynamics of power and privilege; the history of social movements; cultural representation; and the history and current status of LGBTQ individuals, communities, and activism in a global context. The minor provides students with critical thinking, research, and communication skills applicable to a wide range of professions in fields such as social work, public health, law, teaching, counseling, journalism, and public policy, as well as to graduate study in the humanities and social sciences.

ProgramName: Minor in Recreation
Requirements:
The Recreation Minor is available to any student in the university. It is designed to provide students with an introduction to the concepts of recreation and leisure. The curriculum allows students to focus their course work in their areas of interest.

The minor requires 18 units of coursework.
Department: College of Health and Human Services

ProgramName: Minor in Religious Studies
Description: A Minor in Religious Studies allows students from any major to supplement their education with the study of the history, beliefs, and practices of world religions. The minor consists of 18 units of coursework chosen in consultation with a Religious Studies advisor.

ProgramName: Minor in Russian
Requirements:
A minimum of 21 units is required for the Minor in Russian.

Required Courses (15 units):
- RUSS 100 - Fundamentals of Russian (4 units)
- RUSS 200 - Intermediate Russian (4 units)
- RUSS 312A - Advanced Russian I (3 units)
- RUSS 312B - Advanced Russian II (3 units)
- RUSS 314 - Introduction to Russian Culture (3 units)

Elective Courses (6 units):
Six units of upper division RGRLL courses selected with the approval of the Russian advisor.
Fees: $7,904/Year (2023-2024 full-time, resident undergraduate tuition and mandatory fees)
Description: The Department of Romance, German, Russian Languages and Literatures offers a minor in Russian. Students who minor in Russian find that their knowledge of the language and culture helps them advance professionally in fields such as international business, law, journalism, and government service. The Russian minor gives students the opportunity to learn one of the world's most significant languages and to understand the unique culture of Russia and Eurasia through their literature, culture, and history. Upon completion of the Minor in Russian, students will be able to: Demonstrate communicative proficiency in Russian at the advanced-mid level according to the ACTFL Guidelines; Demonstrate understanding of the literatures and cultures of the Russian-speaking world and develop an awareness of their diversity; Analyze and interpret original works from diverse literary and cultural traditions of the Russian-speaking world using critical concepts and methods appropriate to the discipline.

ProgramName: Minor in Sociology
Requirements:
To declare the Sociology Minor, students should go to the Sociology Department Office (MH-205) to file the appropriate form.

The Minor in Sociology consists of 18 units, including the following:
1. SOC 100, Principles of Sociology (3 units)
2. Three units of Sociology at the 200-level (3 units)
3. Twelve units of any upper-division Sociology courses (300- or 400-level) (12 units)

ProgramName: Minor in South Asian Studies
Description: The South Asian Studies minor at CSULB offers students an interdisciplinary program of study in the cultures, histories, languages, politics, and social dynamics of the South Asian region. Students take courses in a variety of departments, including Asian American Studies, Comparative World Literature, English, History, Religious Studies, and Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies. Students may also study South Asian languages through independent study and study abroad opportunities. The minor is flexible, allowing students to tailor the program to their specific interests.

ProgramName: Minor in Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages (TESOL)
Requirements: The TESOL Minor consists of 18 units and is available to all undergraduate students in good standing. Students must earn a “C” or better in all courses required for the minor. Completion of LING 170 with a grade of “C” or better is prerequisite to all upper-division courses in the minor.
Description: The Minor in Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages (TESOL) is designed to provide undergraduate students with a strong theoretical and practical foundation in the field of TESOL. This minor prepares students to teach English in various international and domestic settings, including private language schools, community programs, and overseas institutions. Students will gain expertise in language acquisition theories, pedagogical methods, curriculum development, assessment techniques, and cultural understanding pertinent to teaching English as a second or foreign language. The program emphasizes hands-on experience through practicum opportunities, allowing students to apply their knowledge in real-world teaching environments. Graduates will be equipped with the skills and knowledge necessary to effectively support English language learners of diverse backgrounds and proficiency levels.

ProgramName: Minor in Translation Studies
Description: Translation Studies is a growing interdisciplinary field that investigates the theoretical and practical aspects of translation and interpreting. The Minor in Translation Studies at CSULB offers students an introduction to the principles, methods, and technologies of translation. Students will develop skills in translating between English and a language of choice, and acquire knowledge of the cultural, social, and ethical dimensions of translation. The minor is designed to complement any major, providing a valuable skill set for diverse career paths in a globalized world. It also serves as a strong foundation for graduate studies in translation or related fields.

ProgramName: Minor in Women's, Gender, & Sexuality Studies
Requirements: The minor in Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies is open to all students. The minor requires a total of 21 units.
Description: The Minor in Women's, Gender, & Sexuality Studies (WGSS) offers students from various majors across the campus the opportunity to gain a critical understanding of the social and cultural construction of gender and sexuality. The WGSS Minor provides students with valuable tools to understand inequalities across different contexts, including race, class, gender, sexuality, nationality, and ability. Our students develop intersectional and transnational perspectives on diverse social issues. These skills are highly valued in a broad range of careers in both the public and private sectors, including law, journalism, public policy, education, health, and social work. Additionally, the WGSS Minor prepares students for graduate study in Gender Studies and related fields.
